title: rethinking2020
text:
This book is a study project of Statistical Rethinking, second edition, by Richard McElreath (McElreath 2020).


To install the rstan package the rstan site provides useful guidance at rstan site.
The sequence to follow is

Ensure Rtools is installed
Ensure rstan is installed
Install rethinking only once



Make sure Rtools is installed before proceeding further.
Get the environment path

sys_path <- Sys.getenv("PATH")
sys_path <- unlist(stringr::str_split(string = sys_path, pattern = ";"))

then find position of RTools and test if it is installed

tmp <- grepl(pattern = "(Rtools)|(RBuildTools)", sys_path, ignore.case = TRUE)
stopifnot(any(tmp))

and verify that g++ can really be called from R

system("g++ -v")
system("where make")




Install rstan and its tools.

install rstan and its tools
install.packages(c("rstan", "rstantools"))

and verify that tool chain works

fx <- inline::cxxfunction(signature(x = "integer", y = "numeric" ) ,
                           'return ScalarReal( INTEGER(x)[0] * REAL(y)[0] ) ;' )

and just a final verification to ensure all is correct

# this should return 10
fx <- inline::cxxfunction(signature(x = "integer", y = "numeric" ) ,
                           'return ScalarReal( INTEGER(x)[0] * REAL(y)[0] ) ;' )
fx( 2L, 5 )
if(fx( 2L, 5 ) == 10L) {
    msg <- paste("RStan installed with success. Version", packageVersion("rstan"))
    message(msg)
} else {
    stop("RStan installation failed.")
}





install.packages(c("coda", "mvtnorm", "devtools"))
library(devtools)
devtools::install_github("rmcelreath/rethinking")


Important rethinking mus be reintalled to work under R 4.0. But it is not on ‘CRAN’ and must be reinstalled locally. Go to solution to solve it. This will show the command on the next lines.

Use the following to install rethinking locally when using R with version >= 4.0.

remotes::install_github("rmcelreath/rethinking")






sessioninfo::session_info()





McElreath, Richard. 2020. Statistical Rethinking: A Bayesian Course with Examples in R and Stan. 2nd ed. Boca Raton, Florida: Chapman; Hall/CRC. http://www.taylorandfrancis.com.

title: 1  The Golem of Prague
text:
All models and computations use the brms package (Bürkner 2021). It is inspired from Solomon Kurtz who did wonderful work. It is all detailed at Solomon Kurtz.
This is important as, rethinking R-rethinking is not used in real-life applications whereas brms is considered a reference.
The loo package Vehtari et al. (2022) is used by both rethinking and brms to compute WAIC and LOO. See chapter 7 Ulysses’ compass, section 7.5, for details.

title: 1  The Golem of Prague
text:
1.2 Using tidyverse
A fundamental role of this study project is, in addition to learning Bayesian statistics, to learn how to use a tool kit which is inseparable from the study of Bayesian stats. Therefore the tidyverse paradigm is used given it’s very elaborate and more ergonomic set of tools.

1.2.1 tidybayes, ggdist, distributional and extraDistr
The ggdist (Kay 2022) and tidybayes (Kay 2020) packages are the work horses of this book. tidybayes relies heavily on the ggdist and reexport very many of it’s functions. In addition ggdist is useful for both a frequencist as well as a bayesian approach.
As a resultggdist will be the first choice, tidybayes will be used when the task is better done with it, in particular for its ability to do the data with brms
The distributional package (O’Hara-Wild, Kay, and Hayes 2022) is used with stat_dist_ functions in ggdist to create slab+interval geoms for analytical distributions.
The extraDistr package (Wolodzko 2020) has many extra distributions such as BetaBinom, NegBetaBinom, HalfCauchy, ZIP, Pareto, etc. which are useful in real-world applications and usually dispersed amongst many different packages.


1.2.2 bayesplot and bayestestR
bayesplot (Gabry and Mahr 2021) and bayestestR (Makowski et al. 2021) are used as complement when ggdist and tidybayes do not provide a satisfactory solution.


1.2.3 Using ggplot2, scales and paletteer
The ggplot2 package (Wickham 2016) has become the standard for ploting in R, no question. There are 2 packages that really help in making plots with ggplot: scales and paletteer
The scales (Wickham and Seidel 2022) has a whole slew of functions to manage scales for visualization.
The paletteer (Hvitfeldt 2021) is a very nice package to manage color and shape palettes.


1.2.4 Using knitr
The knitr package (Xie 2022) was used for rmd documents whereas this project uses the new quarto standard. Still, some functions from knitr can be useful and still such as the one to create bibliography.

# to write references, use this command
knitr::write_bib(c("knitr"), width = 80)
